The Angry Birds Movie (2016) – Animated Comedy

Let’s be honest here—this movie is very rough. It’s not a polished, groundbreaking animated film by any means. But with that being said, it’s still enjoyable enough for young children. They get the thrill of seeing their favorite Angry Birds video game characters brought to life in a theatrical feature, and in that regard, it delivers what they want.

The voice acting cast is perfectly fine. Everyone does a solid job with their delivery, and the director deserves credit for piecing the film together as best as possible. The issue comes down to the writing. The comedy is present, but it doesn’t land the way it needs to. A lot of the dialogue feels lapse and slightly off, and overall the script gives off the vibe of being rushed rather than carefully developed. It feels undercooked when it easily could’ve been more clever and appealing across all ages.

That’s really where the problem lies—this movie does not appeal to adults or even teenagers in any significant way. And that matters, because parents are the ones rewatching films like this alongside their kids over and over again. The best animated films succeed because they balance humor and storytelling for both children and adults, but The Angry Birds Movie leans entirely toward little kids, leaving adults bored and disengaged.

Now, it’s not unwatchable. It has enough energy and silliness to keep kids entertained, and it’s definitely rewatchable if you have young children who want to see it again. But outside of that, it lacks substance, wit, and charm.

I’m not going to score this one high. However, I will give it a very slight thumbs up—not because it’s a great film, but because it serves its purpose for the younger generation. It’s not completely rotten, but it’s also far from soaring.
